title: About Me
text:
I am a third-year doctoral student in the clinical psychology program at Boston University (BU) co-mentored by Dr.¬†Yakeel Quiroz and Dr.¬†Alice Cronin-Golomb. I completed her bachelor‚Äôs degree at Fordham University with a major in Psychology and an MS in Neuropsychology from Benemerita Universidad Aut√≥noma de Puebla. Prior to becoming a student at BU, I worked as a Research Assistant for University of California San Diego. Broadly, her research interests include sex differences in aging populations and how reproductive factors unique to women may be related to higher rates of AD and dementia in women. I was awarded an NINDS F31 grant in 2024 to examine the sex-specific effects on white matter integrity and brain function in autosomal dominant Alzheimer‚Äôs disease and vascular dementia.



I am part of the R-Ladies Global Team. R-Ladies promotes gender diversity in the R community, I highly recommend you join our community slack! I am also a co-organizer of R-Ladies Puebla, you can find all of our great content, here.



Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or would like to discuss potential projects.
This personal website was developed using Quarto.

title: Introductions + Hello
text:
Hello! My name is Averi Giudicessi, I am a clinical psychology doctoral student living in the Boston area with my partner and dog Robbie (pictured below). Follow along to see what projects I am working on in my doctoral program and beyond.



Robbie in San Diego


I am currently in a busy second year of my doctoral program and hope to write more about my research and upcoming projects here more often. For now I will leave you with this picture of my really cute dog enjoying the San Diego sun.

title: Averi Giudicessi
text:
Hello! üëã
My name is Averi Giudicessi and I‚Äôm a PhD Student in Clinical Psychology at Boston University
üß† My research interests include understanding sex differences in older adults and how reproductive factors unique to women may be related to higher rates of Alzheimer‚Äôs disease and dementia in women. I use structural and functional neuroimaging, and cognitive data to try and understand some of these questions.
